questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A Cisco ACI fabric displays this fault. Which set of actions modifies the event to be displayed as a warning in the future?

choices.B:
Navigate to the ACI Fault tab.
Create a new record.
choices.D:
Navigate to the ACI Fault tab.
Change the severity level.
choices.C:
Navigate to the ACI Events tab.
Change the severity level.
choices.A:
Navigate to the ACI Events tab.
Create a new record.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A and C (Navigate to Events tab): Faults and events are managed separately in Cisco ACI. The severity of faults must be changed in the Faults tab, not in the Events tab.

Selected Answer: C
As the questions are from an old version of ACI where there were two Fault and Events tabs (ACI 4.0), this question can be confusing.

I looked in my laboratory (ACI 5.0) and you can change it within the Faults tab, but within Faults you need to be in Events (which is no longer separated like in the ACI 4.0 version).

I'll go with alternative C

Selected Answer: D
The question is about Faults, not Events, so Fault tab is correct.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/all/faults/guide/b_APIC_Faults_Errors/b_IFC_Faults_Errors_chapter_01.html#id_65132

Selected Answer: D
its D I just did the change on my ACI Lab

fault tab and change severity
just checked on my ACI

Selected Answer: C
In the Events tab of an APIC GUI component, you can change the severity of a displayed event or you can suppress (squelch) it altogether.

Step 1: Navigate to the Events tab that currently displays an instance of the event.

Step 2: Choose one of the following actions:

To change the severity of these events, right-click the row of the desired event code, select Change Severity, select the desired severity level, and click Change Severity.
To prevent these events from appearing in event reports (squelching the event), right-click the row of the desired event code, select Ignore Event, then click Ignore Event.

With either of these actions, a dialog box appears in which you can confirm the selected action. In both cases, the dialog box displays the path to the Affected Monitoring Policy, which will be automatically modified as a result of the action. To undo the action later, you can navigate to this policy and manually modify it as described in Changing Event Severity or Squelching an Event in the Monitoring Policy.

Selected Answer: C
seems C is right from 4.2(1) on.
"You can change the severity or squelch an event directly from the Events table instead of from the monitoring policy." https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/all/faults/guide/b_APIC_Faults_Errors/b_APIC_Faults_Errors_chapter_0100.html

Selected Answer: D
Could be D.

Selected Answer: A
It is A, because ARP requests must be managed via Layer 3 unicast packets or be dropped to reduce excessive broadcast traffic. 
Since there is no option for hardware proxy, disabling ARP is the only option to choose.

Selected Answer: A
A seems correct

Selected Answer: A
a is the one

Selected Answer: A
Unicast Routing: If this setting is enabled and a subnet address is configured, the fabric provides the default gateway function and routes the traffic. Enabling unicast routing also instructs the mapping database to learn the endpoint IP-to-VTEP mapping for this bridge domain. The IP learning is not dependent upon having a subnet configured under the bridge domain.

Limit IP Learning To Subnet: Prevents the local IP endpoint from being learned outside the subnets configured on the bridge domain. Prevents mis-learning of IP addresses that may not belong to the fabric.

ARP Flood is off: ARP Request is handled as L3 Unicast

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct

comments.content: B not correct just confused and agree is A with frzzt Thank

I think B is correct

choices.B:
Enable Limit IP Learning to Subnet.
Enable Unicast Routing on the bridge domain and configure a subnet.
Set Multi-Destination Flooding to Flood in BD.
choices.D:
Enable Unicast Routing on the bridge domain and configure a subnet.
Set L2 Unknown Unicast to Flood.
Disable Endpoint Retention Policy.
choices.C:
Set Endpoint Retention Policy to default.
Enable ARP Flooding.
Enable Unicast Routing on the bridge domain and configure a subnet.
choices.A:
Disable ARP Flooding.
Enable Limit IP Learning to Subnet.
Enable Unicast Routing on the bridge domain and configure a subnet.

questions.question_text:
A bridge domain for a new endpoint group in the Cisco ACI fabric must meet these requirements:
• The bridge domain must function as the default gateway for the subnet so that routing remains within the Cisco ACI fabric.
• ARP requests must be managed via Layer 3 unicast packets or be dropped to reduce excessive broadcast traffic.
• The impact of misconfigured virtual machines must be kept to a minimum by preventing IP addresses outside of the configured subnet from being routed.

Which set of actions must be taken?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D
https://community.cisco.com/t5/data-center-and-cloud-knowledge-base/aci-unmanaged-mode-configuration-example-using-asav-in-routed/ta-p/3313318

configuration examle.

choices.A:
Configure a policy-based redirect subject.
Associate the policy-based redirect subject with All_Traffic_Allowed.
choices.C:
Configure a device interface policy.
Associate the device interface policy with FW-Device.
choices.D:
Configure a service graph.
Associate the service graph with All_Traffic_Allowed.
choices.B:
Configure a firewall bridge domain.
Associate the bridge domain with FW-Device.

questions.question_text:
An engineer configures a one-armed policy-based redirect service insertion for an unmanaged firewall. The engineer configures these Cisco ACI objects:
• a contract named All_Traffic_Allowed
• a Layer 4 to Layer 7 device named FW-Device
• a policy-based redirect policy named FW-1Arm-Policy-Based RedirectPolicy

Which configuration set redirects the traffic to the firewall?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
To resolve this issue, you need to prune VLAN 101 from the VLAN pool associated with the egress L3Out. This ensures that there is no overlap between the VLANs used for the L3Out (e.g., OSPF adjacency) and those used for EPG traffic.

Selected Answer: D
D
I guess D is the only reasonable answer. B makes no sense.

comments.content: probably yes, because and L3 out vlan and a static binding vlan assigned to an EPG should not be in the same vlan pool, if I´m not wrong

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think this is D.

choices.A: Use VLAN 101 for OSPF adjacency on the egress L3Out.
choices.C: Add VLAN 102 to the VLAN pool that is used by the static port binding.
choices.B: Use VLAN 102 as the encap VLAN on the EPG-101 static port binding.
choices.D: Prune VLAN 101 from the VLAN pool that is used by the egress L3Out.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The Cisco ACI fabric has an egress L3Out from Leaf-101 and Leaf-102 to CORE-1. VLAN 102 is used to form the OSPF adjacency. The workloads must be migrated into EPG-101, and the static port binding is configured to Leaf-103 e1/1 with encap VLAN 101. An engineer completes the port binding and receives an MCP fault. Which action clears the fault?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I'm not really sure, but I think it should be C. Because in the picture there is a VLAN pool dynamically assigned.

comments.content: Uses a dynamic VLAN pool instead of a static pool, which is incorrect because the requirement specifies a specific tagged VLAN ID (100). Dynamic allocation cannot guarantee this.

discussion.content: A must be the right answer, The difference between A & C is the name of the domain
untagged should be unselected because it should be a trunk port? due to it being connected to an ESXi host with several port groups?

Selected Answer: A
Specifically : tagged VLAN ID of 100 - so static, not dynamic. tagged 100 - so untagged unselected

Selected Answer: A
n ACI, you can create a VLAN pool with allocation type static or dynamic. With static allocation, the fabric administrator configures a VLAN; with dynamic allocation, the APIC assigns the VLAN to the domain dynamically....In this case question is asking for static VLAN.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The EPG-100 must be extended to the vCenter as a port group with a tagged VLAN ID of 100. Which set of actions accomplishes this goal?

choices.A:
1. Define a static VLAN range (from 100-200) under a VLAN pool that is associated with the dc1vcdev domain.
2. Associate the dc1vcdev domain with EPG and select these settings:
• Untagged VLAN Access: unselected
• VLAN Mode: Static with Encap: 100
choices.D:
1. Define a dynamic VLAN range (from 100-200) under a VLAN pool that is associated with the dc1vdev domain.
2. Associate the dc2vcdev domain with EPG and select these settings:
• Untagged VLAN Access: selected
• VLAN Mode: Static with Encap: 100
choices.C:
1. Define a dynamic VLAN range (from 100-200) under a VLAN pool that is associated with the delvdev domain.
2. Associate the dc1vcdev domain with EPG and select these settings:
• Untagged VLAN Access: unselected
• VLAN Mode: Static with Encap: 100
choices.B:
1. Define a static VLAN range (from 100-200) under a VLAN pool that is associated with the dc1vcdev domain.
2. Associate the dc2vcdev domain with EPG and select these settings:
• Untagged VLAN Access: selected
• VLAN Mode: Static with Encap: 100
